content.description: The crux is getting through the first few bolts. There's some excitement pulling the bulge, and good climbing to the chains.
content.location: It is number 3 on the current topo.

content.description: Don't let your guns deceive you.
content.location: This is currently the first route to the right of The Bumbler. Look for a bad belay stance just right of / in a dirty looking corner system, and bolts on a left-facing wall.

content.description: Put your 'cipherin' ablilities to the test. This route requires some strategery to get through the crux. There's an 11d/12a crux between the first and second bolts, followed by a harder crux between the second and third bolts. It's not completely over till the last bolt. Bring a 60m rope.
content.location:
Cross the creek at the footbrige, follow the climber trail down stream a quarter mile or so. Bushwhack to the tower-like buttress, shown in the

The Prow topo.

.

content.description:
Climb the first five bolts of

The Bumbler

, then stay left aiming for the splitter crack high on the headwall. Climb the stellar crack, then stay right of the dihedral at the top on nice pockets.
One of the better routes in this area.
The Bumbler has tricky climbing up a right-facing corner onto a ledge. This serves as the first pitch to Rumble On and Rumble in the Bumble.

After topping out on

The Bumbler

, there are two pitches above - Rumble in the Bumble, 11c (left) and this route, Bumble On (right). For this route, from the ledge, climb up and slightly right through a shallow, dihedral crack system.

The Bumbler

The Bumbler

and Bumble On can be combined into one pitch with a 70m rope.

Survivin' expert!

This route was put up on lead over 3 days and involved a few aid falls even.  It ended up being very well-protected (maybe a tad over protected) but very good nonetheless.  The route is easily identified by a large, left-facing corner starting at bolt 5.  This corner is clean, fun, and probably the crux of the sustained route.  Clip long slings on bolts 8 and 16 and also on the two pins at the roof near the top of the route.  The pins were great when we did the route, but be sure to check them before clipping them.  The second one has a nice tied off hero loop to clip.  There are opportunities to back these pins up with medium wires and small cams.
content.protection:
16 quickdraws and 4 shoulder runners to a bomber 1/2" coldshut and chain anchor.

THIS ROUTE REQUIRES A 70 METER ROPE TO LOWER.

We removed some big blocks up and right on the top of the route; however, be vigilant as the upper section of the climb still has loose rock to either side of the easiest climbing.  Also, keep this in mind when lowering or rapping.

content.description: The crux is down low, and the difficulty eases off after the dihedral. This may be easier than 12b.
content.location: It is number 4 on the current topo.
